The image shows the Tropical Storm Zeta forecast by the National Hurricane Center (NHC) as of 5:00 AM EDT on October 26th, 2020. Zeta is expected to make landfall in Mexico later that day or night, move over the southern Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday, and approach the northern Gulf Coast on Wednesday. Zeta has maximum sustained winds near 70 mph (110 km/h) with higher gusts, and it is forecast to strengthen further before making landfall. Tropical storm conditions are expected in parts of Mexico by late today, while hurricane conditions are expected within the Hurricane Warning area near and to the north of where Zeta makes landfall. The advisory also mentions that rainfall totals of 4 to 8 inches with local amounts of 12 inches are possible across parts of Mexico, the Cayman Islands, and central to western Cuba. Storm total rainfall of 2 to 4 inches with isolated amounts of 6 inches is expected across portions of the central U.S. Gulf Coast, Tennessee Valley, southern Appalachians, and Mid-Atlantic States near and in advance of Zeta. The advisory also notes that a dangerous storm surge will raise water levels by as much as 1-3 feet above normal tide levels along the immediate coast in the Hurricane Warning area near and to the north of where Zeta makes landfall. The next intermediate advisory is expected at 8:00 AM EDT, and the next complete advisory will be issued at 11:00 AM EDT.

However, I can provide information on how to estimate the peak impact magnitude at any given location based on the forecasted intensity and distance from the center of the storm.

To estimate the peak impact magnitude at a specific location, you need to know the maximum sustained wind speed (in mph or km/h) and the minimum central pressure (in mb or inches). The peak impact magnitude can be estimated using the following formula:

Peak Impact Magnitude = (Maximum Sustained Wind Speed in mph or km/h) x (Distance from the center of the storm in nautical miles)

In this case, let's assume that the maximum sustained wind speed at Port of Charleston, SC is 70 mph (113 km/h), and the minimum central pressure is 984 mb (29.06 inches). To estimate the peak impact magnitude at Port of Charleston, we need to know the distance from the center of the storm. Assuming Port of Charleston, SC is approximately 500 nautical miles away from the center of the storm, we can calculate:

Peak Impact Magnitude = (70 mph or 113 km/h) x (500 nautical miles) = 35,000 mph or 56,500 km/h

This is a very rough estimate and actual conditions may differ based on the specific track of the storm and local weather patterns. It's always best to monitor local forecasts and warnings for the most up-to-date information.
